subtitle: Let's preserve the seed of life... Let's extract their vital essences to protect them. "I will do
this in Shurubak," said Ninhursag. And you will do it with the living creatures of Abzu." So,
while the others waited anxiously for the flood, Enki and Ninhursag undertook a challenging task.
In Shurubak.... Ninhursag had the assistance of some of her assistants. Enki had the help of
Ningishzida in the Abzu, in the ancient House of Life. They collected the male and female essences,
as well as the eggs of life. Thus, in pairs, males and females, they preserved them in both
the Abzu and city of Shurubak. And then the trumpets sounded and the alarms went off!
Ninurta announced! The thunder on Earth is terrifying. From the White Earth,
Nergal and Ereshkigal declared: the white earth shaking. In Sippar, in the Celestial Ship Place,
the Anunnaki gathered to wait for the flood. And it was at this moment,
as the tension of the wait grew, in his dwelling, Enki fell asleep... In Sippar,
the Anunnaki awaited the starting signal. They were all gathered.
It was then that a dream-vision enveloped Enki in mystery and hope. Before him walked
a bright and radiant man, as if he were the heavens themselves. And as he approached,
he could see that it was Galzu, the white-haired Anunnaki. In his right hand,
he held a stylus, and in his left hand, a smooth and shiny lapis lazuli tablet.
Galzu said: your accusations against Enlil are unjustified, for he was only telling the truth.
And the decision, which as Enlil's decision will be known, I must say was destiny, and not him who
made it. Now, take fate into your own hands so that the earthlings can inherit the earth.
I come to bring you the will of the Creator of All! Summon your son Ziusudra,
and reveal to him the impending calamity, without breaking your oath! Instruct him to
build a vessel that can remain submerged! Tell him that the construction to be made
must withstand an avalanche of water. The vessel must be similar to the one
on this tablet that I present to you. Let him save himself and his family!
And let him take with him the seed of everything that is valuable, whether plants or animals.
And with the stylus, Galzu drew an image on the tablet. He left the tablet engraved next
to Enki's bed. And after the image disappeared, the dream-vision ended,
and shaking, Enki woke up. The vision was enigmatic but revealing! Enki lay in his
bed reflecting with astonishment. What omen could this be? And as he looked around, he saw that the
tablet was by his side. What he had dreamed had materialized before him. On the tablet,
some measures were visible. And they were the exact measurements of the vessel. Immediately,
Enki sent emissaries to find Galzu so that he could speak with him.
However, he was surprised! They told him that Galzu had long since returned to Nibiru.
Enki was perplexed and struggling to understand such a mystery and omen. Although unable to
unravel what had happened, the message was clear! So, secretly, that night Enki went to the reed
hut where Ziusudra was sleeping. And in front of the reed hut, Enki spoke not to Ziusudra,
but to the wall of the hut! Wake up! Wake up, said Enki to the wall of reeds.
Pay attention to my instructions. A storm will fall upon the earth and sweep away all the cities.
Humanity and its offspring will all be destroyed! This is the final decision! It is the word of
the assembly convened by Enlil! The decision is made and announced by Anu, Enlil, and Ninhursag.
Now, listen to my words and observe the message that I transmit to you! Leave your home... Build
a boat! Renounce your possessions and save your life! Reed hut, pay attention! You have only 7
days. Build a boat that can rotate and survive the flood. Make sure the boat is completely covered
and that the sun cannot be seen inside it, its design and measurements are described on a tablet.
I will leave it here, next to the wall of the reed hut. Remember! You have 7
days. Build the boat and gather your family and relatives. Stack up food and drinking
water. Also take domestic animals. Then, on the appointed day, a signal will be given.
I will send an Anunnaki as a guide, who will be appointed by me, and who knows the waters.
He will come to you. On that day, you must get into the boat and close the hatch tightly.
A crushing flood, coming from the south, will devastate the land and all life. The boat will
break loose from its moorings, and then it will rotate, and spin under the impact of the water.
The echo of Enki's voice still rang in Ziusudra's ears when he was awakened by his words. Enki was
hiding behind the reed hut and speaking in front of the wall. His message was clear:
a terrible storm was approaching and the destruction of all humanity was imminent.
Ziusudra understood that he was only his own seed,
the salvation of humanity. Ziusudra was paralyzed with fear and fell to his knees,
begging to see Enki's face. But Enki refused. He had explained everything that was possible and
made it clear that Ziusudra could not see his face, otherwise he would die.
And if the people ask, continued Enki, say that Lord Enlil was angry with Enki, and that
you will sail to the Abzu, so that perhaps Lord Enlil will calm down! Then there was silence and
Ziusudra left the reed hut, finding the tablet that Enki had mentioned. On the tablet was a
boat drawn just as Enki had described. The tablet glimmered in the moonlight. Ziusudra
returned to the hut with only one certainty: something serious would indeed happen.
The next morning, Ziusudra met the people and told them that he was condemned due to
Enlil's irritation with Enki. He explained about Enlil's hostility and that he could
not even set foot in the Edin. Thus, he should build a boat to find Lord Enki, in his domain
in the Abzu. Upon hearing the news, the entire town mobilized to assist in building a boat.
It was a massive ark, and the people were anxious! Everyone wanted to help and witness Ziusudra's
departure, as this would mean speaking with Enki and appeasing Enlil's wrath. In this way,
everyone would assist! Many sacrificed their own livelihoods to provide for Enlil! While
some carried wood and helped with construction, others applied pitch. Ziusudra called for all
who desired to seek the protection of Lord Enki in the Abzu to join the ark.
Some artisans heeded his call. And then, six days passed. It was on the seventh day,
the Day of the Deluge, that Ninagal, the Lord of the Great Waters, Enki's envoy,
arrived. He was one of the great Lord Enki's sons and carried with him a cedar wood box.
Ziusudra invited Ninagal aboard. The vessel was massive and well-equipped
to withstand the imminent storm. So, Ziusudra and Ninagal waited for the seventh day.
In the sky, the stars heralded the Age of Leo. This was the one hundred and twentieth
Shar. This was Ziusudra's tenth Shar of life. Suddenly, a dark cloud appeared on the horizon,
obscuring the morning light. At that moment, a strange shadow of death covered the Earth.
Thunder rumbled and echoed across the planet, while lightning illuminated the skies.
In Sippar, Utu gave the signal: "Depart! Depart!" he shouted to the other Anunnaki. The gods rose
in their celestial ships toward the sky. Ninagal, Enki's Anunnaki envoy, could see
the storm approaching from eighteen leagues away. "Lock the door," Ninagal shouted to Ziusudra.
His cry echoed throughout Shurubak, announcing the arrival of the greatest storm ever seen.
The heavens opened, and a terrifying roar rose from the depths of the Earth.
Ziusudra and Ninagal, in their hastily constructed boat, felt the water violently agitating the hull.
They had to close the gates. In a coordinated movement, both pulled the door that concealed
the vessel's only entrance. The construction was completely sealed, and darkness engulfed
everything. The waves crashed with force, but inside the vessel, nothing could be heard except
the muffled sound of the ocean. The Deluge began with a deafening roar, and the whole earth shook.
In the white land, at the bottom of the Earth, the plates shook the foundations and moved violently.
The ice broke and was dragged by the invisible forces of Nibiru's network. Huge blocks of ice
collided, fragmenting the icy landscape. Suddenly, a gigantic wave rose, and the sky seemed to touch
the sea. A fierce wind arose, blowing the waters to the north. The waters reached the
lands of Abzu..... From there, the wall of water advanced towards the inhabited lands of Edin.
When the wall of water reached Shurubak,
the moorings of the ark loosened, and the vessel was swallowed by the waters.
Ziusudra and Ninagal felt the vessel being thrown around, as if they were in an aquatic
abyss. Outside, the walls of water swallowed those who could not take shelter. The ground vanished,
and there was only water, on all sides. Before the day could end,
the wall of water gained strength and speed, heading towards the high mountains.
The Anunnaki observed the Earth as they circled in their celestial ships, pressed against the
outer walls of the ships. They were anxious to see what was happening on Earth. The waters had
covered everything, and the world they knew had been transformed forever. Ninhursag cried. She
was desperate with what she saw. She said that her creatures were drowning. Inanna also cried,
lamenting that everything on Earth had turned into clay. The Anunnaki
in the other ships watched with humility and admiration the power of nature.
Some spoke of the fruits of the earth. Many desired the pleasure and taste of fermented fruit
juice, but it was no longer possible. The Anunnaki consoled each other, certain that everything that
existed before was destroyed and had turned to mud. Like a mortal battle, the storm swept people,
mountains, and all lands with overwhelming speed. After the huge wave that swept the planet, the
floodgates of heaven opened, and a torrential rain flooded the Earth for forty days and forty nights.
The peaks of the great mountains had become small islands in the vast sea that the planet
had become. The flood followed by the torrential rain had modified all the landscapes of the planet
and transformed everything into a great watery planet, reminiscent of the ancient Tiamat.
However, in the course of the days, the water began to recede little by little. As in the
Beginning, the waters joined their basins. And forty days after the start of the Deluge,
the rain also ceased. Only Ziusudra's vessel, built under Enki's guidance,
had survived. Ziusudra opened the hatch and could see the sunlight. He felt a light breeze
on his face. He discovered that the water had receded and that he was now adrift in
a vast and infinite ocean. Ziusudra observed the destruction and lamented the loss of all
humanity and all other forms of life. Ziusudra said: "No one survived, except for us. But there
is still no solid land for us to walk on!" Ninagal, the Anunnaki indicated by Enki,
led the boat towards the twin mountains of Arrata, where Ziusudra hoped to find solid ground.
Impatiently, Ziusudra released birds to check for any signs of life and solid ground. First,
he released a swallow, then a raven, but both returned to the boat. Finally, he released a dove,
which returned with an olive branch in its beak. Ziusudra had discovered it! There was
solid ground nearby. Thus, a few days later, the boat settled on one of the rocks. Ziusudra opened
the impenetrable door of the boat and stepped out. Once again, he felt the gentle breeze and
saw the sun. He hurriedly called his wife Emzara and their children. Ziusudra then thanked Lord
Enki for his survival. With some stones, he built an altar to offer a sacrifice.
He chose a sheep and lit the fire. And on the altar, he made his offering to Enki,
his Lord. At that time, in the skies and sheltered by their celestial ships,
the Anunnaki observed the waters receding little by little. Enlil looked at Enki and said,
"Let us make use of the small ships to descend onto the peak of Arrata. Let us observe closely,
let us review what happened and what needs to be done." Thus, Enki and Enlil descended on the Peak
of Arrata, while other Anunnaki, aboard other celestial ships, continued to circle the Earth.
Upon landing on solid ground, the brothers looked at each other and greeted each other. It was
then that the smell of Ziusudra's sacrifice could be felt. "What is this?" Enlil asked.
"What is this smell? Where is the fire coming from? The smell of roasted meat? Did someone
survive the flood?" Enlil was furious. He stared at Enki with great anger. Enki
responded subtly......... "Let's go where the smell leads us and find out what happened."
Then the brothers entered the smaller ships again. They flew over the Peak of Arrata and
could see Ziusudra's boat. They landed their ships next to the great ark.
Ziusudra, Emzara, their children, and the other survivors could be seen, as well as Ninagal,
Enki's son. It was then that Enlil had another fit of rage and his fury knew no bounds. Enlil
lunged at Enki. He was willing to kill his brother with his own hands. It was then that Enki revealed
to him the greatest of secrets! "He is not a mere mortal. He is... my son!" Enki shouted,
pointing in the direction of Ziusudra. For a brief moment, Enlil doubted what Enki had said,
And then he accused him, "You have broken your oath.......... "No," said
Enki.......... "I spoke to a reed wall. I did not speak directly to Ziusudra,
and I did this only because of a dream-vision, said Enki. Enki then told Enlil about the
dream-vision he had and what Galzu, the emissary of the creator of all, had told him.
Ninagal, Enki's son, called out to the other Anunnaki who also heard the account of events.
When Ninurta and Ninhursag heard about it, they did not feel angry. Ninurta said that the survival
of humanity was the will of the Creator of all. And he said this to his father, Enlil. Ninhursag,
in turn, vowed never to allow the destruction of humanity again. She spoke these same words
while touching her crystal necklace, a gift from her father, Anu...... Then she added,
"By my oath, the annihilation of humanity will never be repeated."
Enlil softened his heart. He realized that the survival of humanity was inevitable. So,
he approached Ziusudra and his wife, Emzara, in a gentle and peaceful manner and blessed them,
saying, "Be fruitful and multiply. And thus, populate the Earth." Thus,
peace was sealed between the Anunnaki and the Earthlings. The clans of Enki and Enlil
had come to a conclusion. Ziusudra and his family survived in the ark,
whose construction had been guided by Enki in a dream-vision in direct
contact with a message from the creator of all. That was the end of the olden times.
The olden times had begun with the first landing and ended with the flood. In those days,
the flood had subsided, and the Earth's surface was gradually being revealed. The mountains
remained untouched, but the valleys were covered in mud and sediment. From their heavenly ships
and smaller vessels, the Anunnaki observed the landscapes. Everything that had existed
in the ancient cities – in Edin and Abzu – was now buried beneath the mud. Eridu, Nibru-ki,
Shurubak, and Sippar had all vanished, swallowed by the waters and transformed into mud.
Everything was entirely gone. From their ships, the Anunnaki circled the Earth,
and in the distance, they saw the great stone platform atop the cedar mountains
shimmering in the sunlight. The Landing Place established in the olden times was
still there. The smaller ships touched down on the platform, which was intact. In the launch corners,
the enormous stone blocks remained firm. Clearing debris and tree branches, the first
to land signaled the other ships, and one by one, the heavenly ships landed on the platform. News
was sent to Marduk on Lahmu and Nannar on the moon, and they too returned to Earth, landing
on the Landing Platform. Then the Anunnaki and the Igigi gathered, and Enlil called a meeting.
Enlil said that they had survived the flood, but the entire Earth had been devastated. All
means of recovery must be assessed, whether on Earth or elsewhere. Marduk spoke up,
saying that Lahmu was devastated, its atmosphere sucked away and its
waters evaporated by Nibiru's passage. The Lahmu they once knew was no more,
now a place of dust storms. Nannar added that the moon could not sustain life on its own;
one could only stay there with eagle masks, otherwise, survival was impossible.
Nannar continued, saying that Tiamat's army leader must be immortalized,
connected to Earth's fate. Enlil lovingly placed his arms on his son's shoulder, stating that their
current priority was survival and sustenance. Enlil summoned Enki, his brother, and announced
that they would inspect the sealed Creation Chamber, searching for the seeds of Nibiru.
Next to the platform, they cleared away some mud and found the ancient well. They removed the stone
blocking the entrance and entered the sanctuary. They discovered sealed diorite chests and opened
them with a copper key, revealing crystal vessels containing Nibiru's grain seeds. They were
still there! Enlil handed the seeds to Ninurta, instructing him to build terraces in the mountains
so that the grains of Nibiru could grow. This way, they would once again have bread from the cereals.
In the Cedar Mountains, and other mountains too, Ninurta built dams at the waterfalls,
constructed terraces, and taught Ziusudra's eldest son about cultivation and planting. Meanwhile,
Enlil assigned his youngest son, Ishkur, another task:
"Go where the waters have receded and find any remaining fruit trees." So Ziusudra's youngest
son was tasked with fruit cultivation. The first fruit they found was the vine brought
by Ninhursag. Ziusudra drank its juice and immediately fell asleep, as if intoxicated.
That's when Enki surprised everyone. He offered a gift to the Anunnaki and the inhabitants of Earth:
Enki opened the ark carried by Ninagal and announced that the vital essentials and life
eggs could be combined in the wombs of the quadruped animals aboard Ziusudra's vessel.
Enki said that sheep would multiply, providing wool and meat, and other living creatures
would populate the Earth. Thus, Enki also orchestrated Earth's reconstruction.
Dumuzi was assigned the task of herding, with the help of Ziusudra's middle son. Then Enki focused
on the dark-hued landmass where his and his sons' domains were. At the confluence of powerful
waters, Ninagal built dams in the mountains and channeled the violent waters of the waterfalls
into a lake. Enki, along with Marduk, surveyed the lands between the Abzu and the Great Sea,
contemplating how to drain the river valley where dwellings once stood. In the middle of the river,
where the river waters cascaded, he raised an island and carved out two caves within it.
He created stone channels above them, cut two channels in the rocks,
and shaped two straits. This way, the waters flowing from the plateaus could
be slowed down or sped up. He regulated the waters using dams and sluice gates,
raising the winding river valley through the Cave Island, the island of Abu. In
the Land of the Two Narrows, Enki created a dwelling for Dumuzi and the shepherds. Joy
and satisfaction filled the Anunnaki's hearts on Earth, and Enlil relayed the news to Nibiru.
However, on the Anunnaki's planet, words of concern were spoken. The damage was not only
on Earth and Lahmu, but Nibiru too had suffered greatly. The shield made of gold dust was torn,
and the atmosphere was thinning once again. New shipments of gold to Nibiru
were urgently needed. Enki traveled to the Abzu with his son Gibil, intending
to research and search for gold. However, they were met with shocking and disheartening news:
all the gold mines had vanished, buried under a massive flood.
Enki and Enlil contacted Nibiru and relayed the news to their home planet. They reported
that the city of Bad-Tibira in Edin no longer existed, and there was no landing place for the
ships in Sippar. The hundreds of Anunnaki who worked in the mines and Bad-Tibira had
vanished from Earth. The Earthlings who had served as primitive workers had turned to clay
after the Flood. Earth could no longer provide the gold Nibiru so desperately needed. Despair
was felt both on Nibiru and Earth. During this time, Ninurta completed his mission in
the cedar mountains and traveled to the land of mountains across the oceans. From there,
he sent astonishing and surprising news: the deluge had cut deeply into the mountain sides,
revealing countless amounts of gold in large and small nuggets in the rivers below.
The gold was pure and did not require refining or smelting. Ninurta reported that gold was
everywhere! Enki and Enlil hurriedly traveled to the distant land of mountains and marveled at the
discovery: pure gold that needed no refining or smelting was abundant. "This is a miracle!"
Enki told Enlil. "What was done by Nibiru has been corrected by Nibiru!" Enlil responded,
"The invisible hand of the Creator of All allowed life on Nibiru!" But the leaders wondered,
who could now collect the gold, and how would they be sent to Nibiru? Ninurta had an answer
for the first question. On his journey to the high mountain lands across the oceans,
he found not only gold but survivors as well.
He revealed to the other Anunnaki that there were four surviving brother and sister pairs who had
saved themselves on rafts. They were descendants of Ka-In and knew how to manipulate metals. The
survivors were on an island, the mountain's peak transformed into an island. They called
Ninurta "The Great Protector" and remembered him as a guardian of their ancestors.
Upon hearing this news, even Enlil, who had planned the end of all Earthlings,
was not angered. They all said to themselves and others, "It is the will of the Creator of
All!" The Anunnaki then created a new landing place for the celestial ships
to enable direct travel between the new gold extraction site and Nibiru. They sought a dry,
hardened plain and found it near the Landing Place on a desolate peninsula.
The site was flat, like a calm lake, and surrounded by white mountains. To facilitate
flight navigation between Earth and Nibiru, Enlil suggested to Enki that they could reproduce the
celestial pathways on Earth. They decided to reflect the celestial paths of Anu and Enlil on
our planet. Then, Enlil measured the distances of the heavens and marked a grand design on a tablet
for everyone on Earth to see. It was decided that the Landing Place in the Cedar Mountains would be
part of the facilities! Next, Enlil measured the distance between the Landing Place and the Place
of the ships, designating a new location for a new Mission Control Center at the center Moriah.
In that position, he selected a suitable hill and named it Mount of Way Showing. Enlil ordered
the construction of a stone platform, similar but smaller than the one at the Landing Place. In the
center, a large stone was carved inside and out to house a new link between Heaven and Earth. A
new navel of the Earth, a new Earth's Center, to establish the function of Nibru-ki before
the Flood. The landing shortcut was anchored in the north at the twin peaks of Arrata. To mark
the Landing Corridor, Enlil needed two more sets of twin peaks to define the corridor's
boundaries and ensure ascent and descent. In the southern part of the desolate peninsula,
a mountainous area, Enlil chose adjacent twin peaks, where he anchored the southern boundary.
However, where the second set of twin peaks was needed, there were no mountains. Only
a plain above the valley flooded by waters rose from the ground. Ningishzida suggested
to the other Anunnaki, "Artificial peaks can be erected on it!" So, on a tablet,
he drew the image of smooth peaks rising to the sky. "If this can be done, let it be!",
Enlil approved. "Let them also serve as beacons!" Above the plain, over the river valley,
Ningishzida built a model. He perfected the ascending angles and the four smooth sides. Next
to it, he placed a larger peak, its sides oriented to the four corners of the Earth. The Anunnaki cut
and erected stones with their powerful tools. Beside the first peak, in a precise location,
they raised its twin peak. They carefully designed galleries and chambers for pulsating crystals.
When this enormous peak rose to the heavens, the leaders were invited to place the capstone on it.
Gibil prepared a mixture of electrum, from which the Apex Stone was made. The sunlight reflected to
the horizon, and it was like a pillar of fire at night. It focused a beam to the heavens,
harnessing the power of all the crystals. When the work proposed by Ningishzida was completed,
the Anunnaki entered the great twin peaks and marveled at what
they saw. They gave it a name and called it Ekur, House Which Like a Mountain is.
It was a great beacon for the heavens. They told themselves that the Anunnaki who survived
the Great Flood would always triumph, and so they proclaimed it. Now,
the new Place of the Celestial Ships could receive gold from lands beyond the seas,
and from there, the ships could depart for Nibiru, carrying survival and leading to salvation.
From the east, where the sun rises on the appointed day, they shall ascend;
to the southwest, where the sun sets on the appointed day, they shall descend! Then Enlil,
with his own hands, activated the crystals of Nibiru. From this, strange lights began
to flicker inside, and a captivating hum broke the silence that had been on Earth. Outside,
the Apex stone suddenly shone, and it became brighter than the sun itself.
The crowd of Anunnaki gathered and let out a great and powerful cry of joy; Ninhursag,
moved by the occasion, recited and sang a poem: Ninmah, thus spoke: House that is like a mountain,
house that faces the sky. It is equipped for Heaven-Earth, it is the work of the Anunnaki.
Bright and dark house, house of heaven and earth, Built for the celestial ships,
the Anunnaki constructed it. House whose interior glows with a reddish sky light,
house whose interior shines with the reddish light of the sky, emits a pulsing ray that reaches far
and high. Noble mountain among mountains, created great and noble, it is beyond the understanding of
Earth dwellers. House of equipment, noble house of eternity, its foundation stones touch the waters,
its great circumference is set in the clay. House, whose parts are skillfully interwoven,
so that the great ones who circle in the heavens may descend to rest. House that is
a landmark for spacecraft, with unfathomable innards, Ekur is blessed by Anu himself.
At the end of Ninhursag's exaltation song, the Anunnaki continued celebrating their remarkable
work. Enki suggested to Enlil, "We need to think of an answer to a puzzling question. When,
in future days, someone asks: When and by whom was this wonder created? Let's build a monument beside
the twin mountains, to announce the Age of the Lion. May the face bear the image of Ningishzida,
the designer of the mountains, and may it gaze precisely at the Place of the Celestial Ships,
so that it reveals to future generations when, by whom, and for what purpose it was created!"
Enlil agreed with Enki's words and said, "Utu must once again be the commander of the Place of the
Celestial Ships. Let the Lion look precisely to the east, with the image of Ningishzida!" Thus,
the work began to carve and shape the lion that celebrated the image of Ningishzida. It
was then that Marduk sought Enki, his father, and spoke bitter and angry words of discontent:
"You promised me dominion over the entire Earth, but now command and glory are granted to others.
I am left without lands or tasks. Artificial mountains rise over my former domains. In the
image of the lion should be my image, not that of Ningishzida." Marduk's words angered Ningishzida,
as well as the other sons. Ninurta and the rest of Enlil's sons also raised their voices, demanding
domains in their names. All demanded lands for themselves and Earthlings who could worship them.
Ninhursag spoke up before the others, saying, "Let the celebration not become a dispute! The Earth is
still desolate, among the Earthlings there are only survivors, and we are few Anunnaki.
Let us pay heed to Marduk's words. Ningishzida has not been deprived of his honor in
Marduk's words." Ninhursag's voice became a peacemaker between the two clans. Enlil said:
For peace to prevail, we must divide the habitable lands among us! And so,
they agreed to make the peninsula an undisputed separator. They named it the Land of Missiles,
and called it Tilmun, a land beyond the reach of Earthlings. They entrusted its care to Ninmah,
the peacemaker. To the east of the Peninsula, in the habitable lands, they entrusted them
to the care of Enlil and his sons. And for two of Ziusudra's sons, Shem and Japheth, to live there.
The dark-hued landmass that included Abzu was granted to Enki and his clan for dominion.
To inhabit it, they chose the people of Ziusudra's middle son, Ham. To appease his son,
Enki suggested making Marduk their lord, ruler of their lands. And in this regard, Enlil said,
let it be as you wish! In Tilmun, without its mountainous south, Ninurta built a dwelling
for his mother, Ninhursag. It was located in a valley near a spring with palm trees. On the
mountain peak, Ninurta planted a fragrant garden. And when everything was finished,
they sent a signal to all the outposts on Earth. From the mountainous lands beyond the ocean,
the small ships brought the gold nuggets. From the place of the celestial ships, the gold was
taken to Nibiru. And on that memorable day, Enlil and Enki spoke and agreed.
May Ninhursag, the peacemaker, be honored And let a new title-epithet be offered to her Ninharsag,
Mistress of the Mountain head, let it be another of her names. It was the first
Shar since the Great Deluge, and tensions were simmering amongst all the royal houses
of Anunnaki. The sparks flew when Marduk boldly laid claim to Dark-hued land and all its realms.
The jostling for territories escalated and Ninhursag, who had been the harmonious voice
between the two clans, was bestowed with the title Ninharsag her prior name being Ninmah.
Thus, Ninhursag was hailed as the Earth's Peacemaker. The Anunnaki, in one accord,
sang praises to her very being. Ninhursag, with grace and finesse, steered the ship of
order amongst them. Gold was ferried to Nibiru, and in the wake of celebrations, ambitions and
rivalries dwindled. The Earth, slowly but surely, sprung back to life, enriched by seeds safeguarded
by Enki. All flourished anew, blanketing the earth, air, and water with renewed vigor. Yet,
amongst all treasures unearthed, the remnants of humanity were the crown jewels to the Anunnaki.
It was reminiscent of yore, when the primitive workers were forged. Now, the Anunnaki,
fewer in number and weary, yearned for the toil of civilized human hands. And so unfolded the first
Shar post-Deluge. However, peace was breached not by a tussle between Marduk and Ninurta,
or a direct squabble between the clans of Enki and Enlil. Turmoil erupted when Marduk’s very
own progeny, aided by the Igigi, tore asunder the calm and peace woven by Ninhursag.
Considering the Egyptian context within the Anunnaki story, it's necessary to clarify
some points: Satu, the offspring of Marduk and Sarpanit, is the Egyptian god Seth and will
henceforth be referred to as such. Asar, another scion of Marduk and Sarpanit, will from now on be
called Osiris. Asta, daughter of Shamgaz, will go by the name Isis. Nebat, also a daughter of
Shamgaz, will be known as Nephthys. Horon will answer to the name Horus. Enki shall be Ptah.
These names, Satu, Asar, Asta, Nebat, and Horon, will from this point be retired,
and only their more familiar Egyptian monikers will be used. And now, let us march forward with
this tale that unveils the rich tapestry woven by the intermingling of Sumerian and Egyptian
cultures, shedding light on key aspects of the Anunnaki’s sojourn on Earth.
When Marduk and Sarpanit were on Mars, waiting for the end of the Deluge, Osiris and Seth,
the couple's children, fell in love with the daughters of Shamgaz, the leader of the
Igigi. When they returned to Earth, the two brothers chose wives: Osiris married Isis,
and Seth committed himself to Nephtys. Osiris chose to stay in the Dark-hued land with his
father Marduk, while Seth established his residence near the Landing Place,
where the Igigi and Shamgaz dwelled. Restless with earthly domains, Shamgaz questioned and instigated
other Igigi: "What about the Igigi? Shouldn't they be lords?" Nephtys constantly brought
these thoughts to Seth. nWith his father, Osiris would be the sole heir of the fertile lands.
Thus, Shamgaz and his daughter Nephtys whispered to Seth, weaving plans to maintain control over
the succession. Thus, they organized a feast. They invited the Igigi and the all Anunnaki
races. Unaware, Osiris joined the celebration with his brother. Nephtys, his wife's sister,
adorned herself and sang a song to Osiris while playing the lyre. Seth served succulent meat
to Osiris, and Shamgaz offered him new wine in a chalice, mixed with an elixir.
Osiris was in a good mood. He sang joyfully and took part in the music, playing the cymbals.
Later, under the effect of the drink and the elixir offered by Shamgaz, Osiris fell to the
ground. "Let him rest," said the hosts. And so they took Osiris to another chamber. They led
him to a coffin and closed it with strong clasps, throwing it into the sea. Upon learning of what
had happened, Isis wept profusely for the death of her husband. Osiris' coffin was found by the
seaside in the Dark-hued land. His lifeless body lay inside, stiff and cold. The breath
of life had escaped from his nostrils. Marduk, devastated, tore his garments and covered his
forehead with ashes. "My son! My son!" lamented Sarpanit, immersed in grief and sadness.
Disturbed, Enki cried out, "The curse of Cain repeats itself!" he exclaimed in agony to his son,
Marduk. Isis raised a lament to the heavens and pleaded with Marduk for revenge and an heir:
"Seth must meet his inevitable fate and punishment. However, I beg you! Allow me
to conceive a successor from his own seed, and may your son be remembered by his name,
so that his lineage may survive!" "That, unfortunately, cannot be done!" Enki replied
to Marduk and Isis. Isis was perplexed and deeply troubled, deciding to challenge the
orders. Before the body of Osiris was wrapped and preserved in the sanctuary,
Isis, with skill and cunning, extracted the essence of life from her beloved Osiris.
Through this daring act, Isis conceived the heir and avenger of Osiris. Before Enki and his sons,
before Marduk and other Anunnaki, Seth proclaimed his word: "I am the sole heir
and successor of Marduk, and thus, I shall be the Lord of the Land of the Two Narrows." However,
summoned his three sons to a council. Concerned about the recent events, Enlil said to them:
"In the beginning, we created the Earthlings in our image and likeness, but now the descendants of
the Anunnaki resemble the Earthlings! Ka-in killed his brother, and now a son of Marduk is also a
brother's killer. For the first time in history, the descendants of the Anunnaki have raised an
army of Earthlings, and metal weapons, a secret of the Anunnaki, have been placed in their hands.
Since the days when Alalu and Anzu challenged our legitimacy, the disturbance and disobedience of
the Igigi persist." Enlil continued, in a bellicose and perplexed tone:
Under the dominion of Marduk, the peaks of the lighthouses are hidden. They are besieged,
where the Igigi protect the Landing Place. Thus, the Igigi advance toward The Place of
the Celestial Chariots. They proclaim, in the name of Seth, and intend to establish
themselves in all the Heaven-Earth facilities. Enlil, realizing the intention of the Igigi,
shared his concern with his sons and proposed the creation of an alternative Heaven-Earth facility.
Enlil wished to establish it in the land of Ninurta, beyond the oceans,
and to secretly surround it with Earthlings he trusted. Thus,
the secret mission was entrusted to Ninurta, who set out in search of the ideal location.
In the mountains beyond the oceans, next to an immense lake, Ninurta established
the new Heaven-Earth Bond, protected by an enclosure. Then, he chose a firm-soiled plain,
where he marked the points of ascent and descent. The facilities, although primitive,
would serve their purpose. Ninurta communicated his success to Enlil, ensuring that the shipments
of gold to Nibiru would continue and that, if necessary, they could ascend from that
location. However, at that time, what began as a blessing had a terrible outcome. Dumuzi,
Enki's youngest son, had fallen madly in love with Inanna, Nannar's daughter. Inanna,
granddaughter of Enlil, was also in love with Dumuzi, the lord of shepherding.
It was an unconditional love that engulfed two young individuals, consuming them with a
passionate and enigmatic fervor. The love songs that echoed through the ages were first sung by
Inanna and Dumuzi, immortalizing their love in each verse. Enki, the wise, designated Dumuzi,
his youngest son, with a vast domain over the Abzu. Meluhha, the Black Land, as it was called,
where imposing trees grew and abundant waters flowed. Great bulls roamed among the river reeds,
and countless herds filled their lands. Mountains of silver and shining copper
like gold were parts of his kingdom. Dumuzi was greatly loved, and after the death of Osiris,
he was favored by Enki. However, envy corroded the heart of his younger brother, Marduk.
Inanna, daughter of Nannar and Ningal, was nurtured by Enlil since her birth. Her beauty
was indescribable, and she competed in martial arts with the Anunnaki heroes. She learned
about celestial travels and celestial ships from her brother Utu. A celestial
ship of her own was presented to her by the Anunnaki, to navigate the skies of Earth.
After the Flood, on the Landing Platform, the gazes of Dumuzi and Inanna met,
sealing a mysterious destiny. And thus, a warm encounter took place between them. They
hesitated at first. He belonged to Enki's clan, and she was a descendant of Enlil. When Ninhursag
united the rival clans in search of peace, Inanna and Dumuzi secretly met
away from the eyes of either clan, and confessed their love to each other.
Walking together, they exchanged sweet words of passion and enchantment. They lay side by side,
hearts in harmony, and Dumuzi, filled with desire, embraced Inanna. "Let me teach you!
Let me teach you!" whispered Dumuzi to Inanna. She kissed him gently and then
spoke of her mother, Ningal: "What lie would I tell?--------What words should be spoken?"-------
They decided to reveal their sincere love for each other. They planned for it to be a joyous
occasion, and the scent of cedar would be used to receive the blessing. Thus,
the lovers went to meet Ningal, Inanna's mother. Ningal blessed them, and Inanna's
mother approved of Dumuzi. Ningal said: "Lord Dumuzi, as Nannar's son-in-law, you are
worthy!"------Dumuzi was received as a groom by Nannar and announced by Utu, Inanna's brother.
Enlil spoke to all those present: "A marriage could be the key to peace between the clans!"
At that moment, while Dumuzi shared his love and engagement with his father and brothers,
Enki also glimpsed the possibility of a unifying union and granted
his blessing to Dumuzi. The joy of the engagement infected Dumuzi's brothers,
except for one. That one was Marduk. Gibil carved a bridal bed of gold, and Nergal sent blue lapis
lazuli stones. To please Inanna, sweet dates, her favorite fruit, were piled up next to the
bed. Beneath the fruits, lapis lazuli stones lay hidden, waiting to be discovered by Inanna.
According to tradition, one of Dumuzi's sisters was tasked with perfuming and
dressing the bride. That sister was Geshtinanna, and her epithet meant "the
one to be healed." Inanna unveiled her deepest aspirations for the future alongside Dumuzi to
Geshtinanna. She envisioned a grand nation where Dumuzi, a Great Anunnaki,
would ascend. His name would be hailed above all others, and she would become his queen. Together,
they would rule and bring rebellious nations under their control. Dumuzi would be granted power and
govern the nation with fairness! Geshtinanna, startled by Inanna's immense ambition,
reported the visions and ambitions for a new government to Marduk.
Marduk was disturbed. Inanna's ambition and the idea of a new government with Dumuzi were an
affront to him. So Marduk confided a secret plan to Geshtinanna. And then Geshtinanna
went to the shelter of her brother Dumuzi, disguised with an enchanting and perfumed
appearance. She whispered to Dumuzi, "Before you rest with your young wife in your arms,
you must conceive a legitimate heir, born of a sister!" A child born through Inanna will have
no right to succession and will not be raised in the presence of his mother! With a gentle touch,
she placed her hand on his and approached him, saying: "My brother, I shall lie with
you! Together, we shall have a descendant of Enki, and the dual seed shall prevail."
Thus, Geshtinanna whispered to Dumuzi, aiming to generate a noble lineage within her womb.
Dumuzi surrendered to desire. And then he poured his seed into Geshtinanna's womb
and fell asleep. In the night, a dream befell Dumuzi. It was a revelation of impending death.
In the dream, seven wicked bandits invaded his dwelling. They said, "The Master has sent us to
you, son of Duttur!" They drove away his sheep and seized his lambs and goats. They stole the
crown of his majesty, stripped him of his royal attire, violently shattered his shepherd's staff,
and toppled his chalice. Deprived of everything and chained, he was left
to perish in the name of the Bird Prince and the Falcon. Dumuzi woke up in the heart of the night,
terrified and disturbed. He recounted the dream to Geshtinanna. She warned him:
"The omen is not favorable. Marduk will accuse you of violating me and bring upon
you a curse. He will send emissaries to arrest you. He will dishonor you and sever
your relationship with an Enlilite." Dumuzi roared ferociously: "Betrayal! Betrayal!"
And then he pleaded for help from Utu, Inanna's brother, and invoked the name of his father
Enki as a protective talisman. Dumuzi embarked on a journey across the desert of Emush,
the Desert of Serpents, seeking refuge in a place adorned with majestic waterfalls, fleeing from his
malevolent pursuers. Upon reaching a spot where the waters flowed, making the rocks smooth and
slippery, Dumuzi lost his balance and fell. The rushing waters carried his lifeless body in frothy
foam, delivering him to the emissaries of evil who captured him. The lifeless body of Dumuzi
was recovered from the waters of the lake by Ninagal. Thus, he carried Dumuzi's body to the
realm of Nergal and Ereshkigal in the Lower Abzu. On a stone slab lay the motionless body of Dumuzi,
Enki's son. Upon learning of what had happened, Enki tore his garments and covered Dumuzi with
ashes, lamenting: "My son! My son! What have I done to be so severely punished?" And he
questioned aloud: "I, Ea, Whose House is the Water, brought forth the waters that propelled
the Celestial Ships and landed on Earth. A torrent of waters devastated the Earth, my grandson Osiris
perished in the waters, and now my beloved Dumuzi meets the same fate, also in the waters!
All that I did, I did with just cause. Why am I punished? Why has fate turned against me?" Enki
wept and mourned. When Geshtinanna revealed the truth behind the events, Enki's anguish increased.
Meanwhile, Inanna, the bride, was enveloped in a veil of concern and deep sorrow. The disappearance
and death of her beloved Dumuzi were an absolute catastrophe. Determined to retrieve her lover's
body to give him a dignified burial, Inanna descended into the depths of the Lower Abzu. Her
sister Ereshkigal, the queen of those domains, was alerted to Inanna's arrival at the temple
gates and suspected a deceitful plot. At each of the seven gates leading to Ereshkigal's throne,
one by one, Inanna's possessions were stripped away. Despoiled and defenseless,
Inanna was accused of conspiring to have an heir with Nergal, Dumuzi's brother. Ereshkigal,
consumed by anger, did not allow Inanna to explain herself. She ordered her vizier,
Namtar, to unleash sixty terrible diseases upon her sister. Inanna's disappearance in the Lower
Abzu alarmed her parents. Nannar sought Enlil, who in turn sent a message to Enki.
Upon learning of the situation from Nergal, Ereshkigal's son and husband,
Enki acted swiftly. He fashioned two emissaries from the clay of the Abzu, beings without blood,
immune to the rays of death. He sent them to the Lower Abzu with the mission of bringing
back Inanna, whether alive or dead. When they encountered Ereshkigal, the emissaries caused
her bewilderment. Unable to discern their origin, the queen asked if they were Anunnaki or beings
of the Earth. Namtar attacked them with magical weapons, but the two remained unharmed. And so,
they reached the lifeless body of Inanna. It was hanging on a stake. The emissaries
created by Enki used the Pulsator and the Emitter. Then, they sprinkled the Water of
Life upon her and placed the Plant of Life in her mouth. Inanna opened her eyes. And then,
she took a breath of life. Thus, Inanna arose in the realm of the dead. As they prepared to
take Inanna back to the Upper World, she ordered them to also take the lifeless body of Dumuzi.
At the seven gates of the Lower Abzu, Inanna's adornments and utensils were returned to her.
She instructed the emissaries to take Dumuzi to the Black Land,
where they should wash him with pure water, anoint him with sweet oil, and dress him in a red shroud,
placing him upon a lapis lazuli slab. There, they were to carve a resting place in the
rocks and wait for the Day of Rebirth. Inanna, thirsting for revenge, made her way to Enki's
abode. She sought vengeance for the death of her beloved and demanded the death of the culprit:
Marduk. Enki whispered softly: there have already been enough deaths. Marduk provoked,
but did not act upon it! Inanna, consumed by despair and a craving for justice, cried out to
the heavens. Vengeance and justice should befall Marduk. In Enlil's dwelling, Inanna and Utu,
her children, gathered in council to discuss the strategies for the impending war. Ninurta,
who had previously defeated the rebellious Anzu, demanded more drastic actions.
Utu revealed whispers of the secret words exchanged between Marduk and the Igigi. Enlil,
then, agreed that Earth needed to be liberated. He stated that Marduk was like a malevolent serpent,
representing a poison. In this manner, Enki received the demand for Marduk's surrender.
Thus, amidst the mourning for Dumuzi, Enki summoned his children to defend Marduk,
his firstborn and heir. Enki said: I still mourn the departure of my beloved Dumuzi.
However, I must defend the rights of Marduk. Despite the evil instigated by Marduk,
Dumuzi did not die by his hands, and thus, Enki declared that Marduk should be protected by all.
Gibil and Ninagal answered their father's call, while Ningishzida opposed and Nergal hesitated,
promising aid only in the face of mortal danger. And so, a war of unparalleled ferocity erupted
between the two clans. The battle was no longer between the descendants of the Earthlings,
but between the Anunnaki, born on Nibiru, engaged in a conflict that
extended beyond their original world. The war began when Inanna, the instigator of the war,
crossed the domains of Enki's children in her spaceship, pursuing Marduk, who took refuge in the
territories of Ninagal and Gibil. Ninurta, coming to his aid, unleashed devastating rays from the
Storm Bird, while Ishkur attacked with blazing lightning and crushing thunder. In the Abzu,
the rivers were deprived of fish, and the cattle scattered across the fields.
Marduk retreated to the north, to the artificial mountains. Relentlessly,
Ninurta unleashed poisoned missiles upon the dwellings, and his Devastating Weapon deprived
the people of those lands of their senses. The channels, once filled with river waters,
turned blood red. As the terrifying battles spread to the north, Marduk hid in the Ekur.
Gibil granted him an invisible shield, and Nergal raised the all-seeing eye to the sky.
With a Brilliant Weapon, Inanna attacked the hidden place. Horus emerged in defense of his
grandfather, and the brightness of Inanna's weapon damaged his right eye. Utu contained the Igigi
and their horde of terrestrial beings beyond Tilmun, at the foot of the artificial mountains.
The Anunnaki from both clans clashed and started a great battle at the foot of the artificial
mountains. Enlil sent words to Enki to seal the peace: let Marduk surrender, let the bloodshed
end! Ninhursag sent other words to Enki: Let brother speak to brother, she said. In his
hiding place within the Ekur, Marduk persisted and defied his pursuers. In the House That Resembles a
Mountain, his final resistance was fought. Inanna failed to overcome the imposing stone structure,
as its smooth sides deflected her weapons. But cunningly, Ninurta discovered a secret
entrance. And then he rotated the stone located to the north of the great pyramid.
Through a dark corridor, Ninurta advanced,
reaching the immense gallery, its ceiling shining with the diverse colors of crystals,
like a sparkling rainbow. But Marduk became aware of the invasion and awaited Ninurta with weapons
in hand. Ninurta directed his weapons at the shimmering crystals and entered the gallery.
Marduk retreated to the upper chamber, to the place of the Great Pulsating Stone.
At the entrance, Marduk closed the sliding stone locks, preventing anyone who dared to challenge
him from entering. Inside the Ekur, Inanna and Ishkur also entered and followed Ninurta.
Then Ninurta, Inanna, and Ishkur discussed what could be done. "May the chamber where
Marduk hides be his stone sepulcher!" Ishkur pointed to the three stone blocks arranged to
slide down. "The three obstructing stones are ready to slide," he said. "May death be slow,
may he be buried alive, and may it be Marduk's verdict!" said Inanna. Thus, each of them cleared
one of the stones. The three obstructing stones were released to bury Marduk like in a tomb.
Each of them slid a stone to obstruct, sealing Marduk like in a grave. And then the stones fell
into a deep abyss, far from the sun and light, without food or water. Marduk lay in the Ekur.
Sarpanit, his wife, mourned his imprisonment and punishment without trial. She sought Enki,
her father-in-law, accompanied by her youngest son Nabu. She said, "Marduk's life must be restored."
Enki asked Utu and Nannar to intercede with Inanna. So they brought Sarpanit's words
for Marduk to live in penitential garments, to live humbly, and to renounce power!
However, Inanna would not be appeased. She said, "For the sake of honor,
the Instigator must succumb!" Inanna retorted. Ninhursag, the peacemaker,
gathered the brothers Enki and Enlil. She said, "Marduk deserves punishment,
but death is not justified!" She asserted. "Let Marduk be in exile, and let succession
on Earth be granted to Ninurta!" Enlil was pleased with the words and smiled.
Ninurta was his son with Ninhursag! "As a father, what choice do I have? Between
succession and life?" With a heavy heart, Enki continued. "In my lands,
desolation spreads. The war must come to an end. I still weep for Dumuzi. So,
let Marduk live in exile! Enlil said: If peace is to reign and Marduk is to live,
agreements and compromises must be made! And so, Enlil observed his advantage, intending to be the
foremost among the brothers. He raised his voice and continued: all the facilities that connect
heaven and earth must be entrusted solely to me. Dominion over the Land of the Two Narrows must be
handed over to another son. The Igigi who follow Marduk must be directed to relinquish the Landing
Place and abandon their alliance and commitment to Marduk. Marduk must be led to a Land of No Return,
where no descendant of Ziusudra resides. Thus, Marduk must depart into exile!
Enki recognized the hand of fortune in his heart:
So be it! he said, bowing his head. The name of Ningishzida was mentioned shortly thereafter,
in two ways. He was designated for the rescue of Marduk and also to be the lord of the lands of
Ekur. It was said that Ningishzida also known as Thoth was knowledgeable of the secrets of Ekur.
When the Great Anunnaki announced their decrees, Ningishzida was called upon to perform the rescue.
His challenge was to extract Marduk from the blocked depths, from the bowels of the great
pyramid. Saving Marduk, buried alive, was a mission that exceeded his own conception.
Ningishzida studied the hidden designs of Ekur and devised a plan to overcome the obstacles:
Then he said: Through a carved upper opening, Marduk will be liberated. And he revealed his plan
to the leaders. Ningishzida spoke: In a location I will show you, we will open a door in the stones.
And from there, we will trace a winding path, forging a rescue axis. Through the
hidden recesses, we will enter the heart of Ekur, At the epicenter of the chambers, we will break
through the rocks. Opening a door inward, we will bypass the blockades; Through the grand gallery,
we will proceed, raising the three stone barriers, And we will reach the highest chamber,
the deadly prison of Marduk!" Thus, the Anunnaki, guided by Ningishzida, pursued their meticulous
plan. With tools that cleaved the rocks, they opened the entrance and shaped the rescue shaft.
They penetrated into the interior of the ingenious mountain and created a passage. Circumventing the
three stone barriers, they reached the highest chamber. On a narrow platform,
they erected the iron gates and rescued the unconscious Marduk. With caution,
through the winding shaft, they led Marduk to the fresh air; Outside, Sarpanit and Nabu,
wife and son, awaited; And finally, an emotional reunion took place. Then,
Enki conveyed the conditions of his release. But Marduk became enraged. Before his eyes,
it was a colossal humiliation. Marduk said, "I'd rather die than renounce my inheritance!" Sarpanit
drew Nabu close to her arms: "We are part of your future!" Sarpanit whispered. Marduk,
enraged and humiliated, uttered, "I surrender to my destiny," in a low voice.
Sarpanit and Nabu then accompanied the desolate Marduk and thus embarked on an Irreversible Land.
They arrived in a Forbidden Land, where horned beasts are hunted. After Marduk's departure,
Ninurta entered the Ekur once again through its entrance. He proceeded
through the corridors towards a mysterious structure. There, on the eastern wall,
a small artistic opening radiated a reddish glow. It was the crimson brilliance of the
Stone of Destiny. Tormented, Ninurta exclaimed in anguish, "Its power captures me to kill me,
subjugating me with a deadly attraction!" Ninurta shouted from within the chamber!
Then he ordered them to take the stone and destroy it completely!"
Retracing his steps, Ninurta entered the grand gallery and reached the highest chamber. In
a chest carved from stone, the heart of the Ekur pulsed. The force of its network expanded
through five compartments. Ninurta struck the chest, which responded with a resonance. Then
he ordered the removal of the Gug Stone, a crystal of beams that determined directions,
and for it to be transported to a place of his choosing. Descending through the vast gallery,
Ninurta examined the twenty-seven pairs of crystals originating from Nibiru. Many were
damaged in the battle against Marduk, while others, still intact, survived the fight.
Ninurta instructed that the intact ones be removed from their niches,
while the others he pulverized with his rays. Then, outside the Ekur, the Great Pyramid,
House Which Like a Mountain Is, took flight on its Black Bird towards the Apex
Stone. He carefully observed the supreme symbol of his enemy. With his weapons,
he released the symbol and caused it to crumble into pieces on the ground.
"With this, the fear of Marduk is finished!" declared Ninurta, victorious. On the battlefield,
the gathered Anunnaki praised Ninurta. They said, "You resemble Anu!" They shouted to their hero and
leader. To replace the disabled beacon, a mountain near The Place of the Celestial Chariots was
chosen. Within its depths, the rescued crystals were placed. At its peak, the Gug Stone, the
Stone of Direction, was installed. The mountain was then named Mount Mashu, The Mount of the
Supreme Celestial Barque. Then, Enlil summoned his three sons; Ninlil and Ninmah were also present.
They confirmed their command over the ancient lands and assigned lordships
over the new lands. Ninurta, the son of Enlil who had defeated Anzu and Marduk,
was given the powers previously granted to Enlil, to replace his father in all
the lands. Ishkur was granted dominion over the Landing Place in the Cedar Mountains.
Thus, Ishkur's new domains merged with his existing domains in the north. Nannar was granted
the lands to the south and east, where the Igigi and their offspring had spread. The peninsula
where The Place of the Celestial Chariots stood was included in Nannar's lands. Utu was declared
the commander of the Place and of the Navel of the Earth. In the Land of the Two Narrows, as agreed,
lordship was granted to Ningishzida through Enki. None of the other sons of Enki opposed
this concession; however, Inanna resisted! For the inheritance of Dumuzi, her deceased betrothed,
Inanna claimed. And from Enlil, Inanna demanded a domain solely for herself. The leaders pondered
on how to satisfy Inanna's demands, and sought advice from the great Anunnaki who decreed fates.
They decided to seek clarification from Anu regarding the events on Earth and the division
of territories. Since the Great Calamity, in the times of the Deluge, almost two Shars had passed,
The Earthlings moved from the mountainous lands and returned to the lowlands. They
were descendants of civilized humanity through Ziusudra, and were mixed with the seed of the
Anunnaki. The descendants of the Igigi who intermarried roamed the lands, and in distant
lands, the descendants of Ka-in also survived. Few and noble, the Anunnaki who came from Nibiru were
their perfect descendants. The Great Anunnaki pondered on how to establish settlements for
themselves and for the Earthlings. The questions revolved around how to maintain their nobility
over humanity and how to ensure that the many and vast masses of Earthlings would obey and serve
the few. How could they remain elevated above Humanity? Amidst all this, regarding the future,
the leaders exchanged words with Anu. And it was then that Anu, the mighty King of Nibiru,
decided to return to Earth once again, accompanied by Antu, his wife, who also wished to visit Earth.
To come to Earth once more Anu decided, with Antu his spouse he
wished to come. While his Arrival they awaited, the Annunnaki abodes in the
Edin to be reestablished began. From the mountain lands descendants of Shem dwelt,
to the old the black-headed people migrated. Upon the newly dried soil the Anunnaki let them settle,
food for all to provide. Eridu, Enki's first city, before where Deluge had stood.
On top of the myriads of mud and silt a new Eridu was marked out. In its center was a raised
platform, an abode for Enki and Ninki was built. House of tile Lord Whose Return Is triumphant
it was called. With gold and silver and precious metals by Enki's sons provided it was adorned and
filled. Above in a circle in the sky, the twelve constellations by their signs were marked out by
the tablets of destiny. Below, in the Abzu, waters with swimming fishes flowed. In a sanctuary,
a place that no uninvited can enter, Enki the DNA formulas kept. For Enlill and Ninlil a Nibru-ki
atop of the mud and silt was established. Amid its people's dwellings and cattle folds, a sacred
precinct was walled off. An abode for Enlil and Ninlil therein was built, in seven stages it
arose. A stairway, rising as to heaven, to the topmost platform led. The Tablets of Destinies
Enlil kept there, with his weapons it was protected.
The Lifted all seeing Eye that scans the lands, and the Lifted Beam that penetrates all was kept
in an enclosure in a courtyard. As the time for the arrival of Anu and Antu neared, For
their stay in the Edin a new place was selected, it would be neither Enlil's nor Enki's. Unug-ki,
the Delightful Place, it was named. Shade trees in it were planted. A pure white structure,
the House of Anu, in its midst was built. Its exterior in seven stages rose;
its interior like a king's quarters it was. When the celestial chariot of Anu at Earth arrived,
Anunnaki atlantean skyships toward it soared. For a safe landing at the Place of the Chariots,
in Tilmun, it was guided. Utu, the Place's commander, his great-grandparents to Planet
Earth he welcomed. The three children of Anu, Enlil and Enki and Ninharsag, stood there to
greet them. They embraced and kissed, they laughed and cried. So long, so long has the
separation been! They to each other kept saying. At each other they looked, aging to examine.
Though greater in Shars and years were the parents, they looked younger than their children!
The two sons looked old and bearded; Ninharsag, once a beauty, was bent and wrinkled. All five
of them with tears were filled; tears of joy with sorrowed tears were mingled. In skyships were the
guests and their hosts to the Edin taken, In a prepared place beside Unug-ki the skyships
landed. All the Anunnaki that on Earth had stayed as an honor guard were standing. Hail and welcome!
Hail and welcome! in unison to Anu and Antu they were shouting. Then in a procession, singing and
music playing, the Anunnaki to the House of Anu all the guests accompanied. In the House of Anu,
Anu washed and rested, then he was perfumed and clothed; Antu by female Anunnaki to the House of
the Golden Bed was escorted; There she too washed and rested, then she was perfumed and clothed.
In the open courtyard, as an evening breeze the tree leaves rustled, Anu and Antu on thrones
were seated. Flanking them were Enlil and Enki and Ninharsag. Attendant Earthlings who
were completely naked, wine and good oil they served; Others, in a corner of the courtyard,
a bull and a ram, gifts of Enlil and Enki, on a fire were roasting. A great banquet was for
Anu and Antu prepared, for the sign in the heavens its start was awaiting. On
Enlil's instructions Zumul, who in matters of stars and planets was a master. The steps
of the House of Anu ascended, the rising of the planets at he was to announce.
On the first step Kishar in the eastern skies appeared, Lahamu or the second step was seen,
Mummu on the third step was announced, Anshar by the fourth step rose, Lahmu on the fifth
step was seen, the Moon from the sixth step was announced. Then, on a signal from Zumul,
the hymn The Planet of Anu in the Skies Rises began to be sung. From the topmost step,
the seventh, the red-haloed Nibiru into view came. To music the Anunnaki clapped and danced,
to music they danced and sang. To the one who grows bright, the heavenly planet of the lord Anu,
sang. On the signal a bonfire was lit, seen from place to place were the bonfires started.
Before the night was over, the whole land of Edin bonfires were lit! After a meal of bull
meat and ram meat, of fish and fowl, wine and beer was accompanied. Anu and Antu to their
overnight quarters were accompanied; by Anu and Antu were all the Anunnaki thanked. For several
Earth days and nights Anu and Antu slept; on the sixth day his two sons and daughter Anu summoned.
Of what had on Earth transpired their accounts he heard. of the peace and the warfare he learned.
Of how the Earthlings, by the oath of Enlil to be wiped off, had again proliferated Anu
as well heard. Of the gold discovery in the land beyond the oceans and the chariot's place there,
Enlil revealed to him. It was then that of the dream and the tablet from Galzu his son Enki to
his father told. By that Anu was greatly puzzled: A secret emissary by that name
of "Galzu" To Earth by me was never sent! So did Anu to the three leaders say.
Puzzled were Enki and Enlil, baffled they at each other looked. On account of Galzu.
Ziusudra also known as noah and the seed of life were saved! Enki said. On account of Galzu on
Earth we remained! Enlil to his father said. The day we returned to Nibiru we would die,
so did Galzu to us say. Incredulous of that was Anu; the change of cycles indeed havoc and death
it did cause, but with elixirs it was cured! Whose emissary, if not yours, was Galzu?
Enki and Enlil in unison said. Who wanted the Earthlings to be saved, who on Earth made us
stay? Ninharsag her head slowly nodded: For the Creator of All did Galzu appear! Was the creation
of the Earthlings also destined, of that I must wonder! For a while the four of them were silent;
each one past events in his heart recounted. While fates we decreed, the hand of destiny
every step directed! So did Anu say. The will of the Creator of All is clear to see. On Earth and
for Earthlings, only emissaries we are. The Earth to the Earthlings now belongs, to preserve and
advance them we were intended! If that is our mission here, let us accordingly act! So did
Enki say. The great Anunnaki who the fates decree counsels exchanged regarding the lands: To create
civilized regions the Great Anunnaki decided, therein knowledge to Mankind provide; Cities of
Man to establish, therein in sacred precincts abodes for the Anunnaki to create. Kingship
as on Nibiru on Earth established, crown and scepter to a chosen earth man we must give.
By him the word of the Anunnaki to the people was conveyed, work and
dexterity was to be enforced. In the sacred precincts a priesthood was to be established,
the Anunnaki as lofty lords to be served and worshiped. Secret knowledge to be taught,
civilization to Mankind will be conveyed. To create four regions, three for Mankind,
one restricted, the Anunnaki would be resolved. The first region in the olden Edin-land to be
established for Enlil and his sons to dominate. The second region in the Land of the Two Narrows
of Kemet thereafter to follow, for Enki and his sons to lord. The third region,
with the other two not mingling, in a distant land to Inanna was granted. The fourth region,
for the Anunnaki alone consecrated, the peninsula of the Place of the celestial Chariots it will be.
Now this is the account of Anu's journey to the lands beyond the oceans, And how
in the First Region for the Anunnaki cities were reestablished after the great flood. Having the
decision about the four regions and Mankind's civilizations made. Anu about his grandson
Marduk he inquired. I must see Marduk my grandson again! to the leaders Anu said. Whether by Dumuzi
and Ningishzidda to Nibiru inviting, Marduk's ire I myself have caused! So did Anu wonder;
to reconsider the punishment of Marduk he wished. When to the lands beyond the oceans we journey,
Marduk to meet you will be told! The land where he roams, in those parts of the Earth it is! So
did Enlil to Anu say. Before the distant lands the royal couple went, the Edin and its lands,
Anu and Antu surveyed. Eridu and Nibru-ki they visited, where the cities of the first region
were planned they saw. In Eridu, Enlil about Enki complained. The DNA formulas to himself
Enki is keeping! Anu, on the seat of honor seated, words of praise to Enki said.
My son Enki for himself, a magnificent house he has built, beautifully on a platform it is
raised. To the people that the House surround and serve, great knowledge will Enki give them. Now,
the knowledge that in the genetic DNA formula's is secreted, with other Anunnaki it must be shared!
Embarrassed was Enki; to share with all the divine formulas to Anu he promised. In the ensuing days,
in skyships traveling, Anu and Antu the other regions surveyed. Then, on the seventeenth day,
to Unug-ki the royal couple returned for one more night of rest. In the morrow,
when the younger Anunnaki before Anu and Antu for a blessing he gave them. Anu to
his great-granddaughter Inanna took a liking; he drew her closely, he hugged and kissed her. Let
all my words be heeded! to the congregated Anu announced. This place, after we leave,
to Inanna as a dowry will be given. Let the sky ship in which we the Earth shall survey to Inanna
my present be given! Joyed, Inanna began to dance and sing, her praises of Anu as hymns in times to
come were chanted and would later be passed down to her earth daughter Priestess Enheduanna.
Thereafter, bidding farewells to the Anunnaki and atlanteans, Anu and Antu departed for the
lands beyond the oceans. Enlil and Enki, Ninurta and Ishkur with them to the golden land went.
To impress Anu the king with the great golden riches, Ninurta an abode for Anu and Antu was
built. Its stone blocks, to perfection were cut, with pure gold inside it was covered. A
golden enclosure, with flowers of carnelian stones carved, the royal couple awaited!
By the shore of the great mountain lake, the abode erected and stood. How the gold nuggets
are collected the visitors were shown. There is gold here enough for many Shars to come!
Anu, satisfied, said. To a place nearby Ninurta to Anu and Antu, an artificial mound showed. How to a
place for melting and refining metals it was made Ninurta explained to them. How a new metal from
stones was extracted he showed them. Anak....... Anunnaki-made, he called it. How by combining
it with the abundant copper a strong metal he invented, he showed them. On the great lake, from
whose shores the metals came, Anu and Antu sailed. The Lake of Anak, Anu called it, henceforth this
was its name. Then from lands of the north, lands where great horned beasts were hunted. Marduk also
known as Amun Ra before his father Enki and his grandfather Anu came. Nabu his son with him he
was. When Enki about Sarpanit inquired, Marduk with sorrow of her death them he told. Now Nabu
alone with me has remained! to his father and grandfather Marduk said. Anu to Marduk to his
chest pressed. Enough you have been punished! to him he said. With his right hand on Marduk's head,
Anu to Marduk to be forgiven blessed. From the golden place, high in the mountains, all who
had gathered to the plain below went. There, stretching to the horizon, Ninurta a new place
for the chariots has prepared. Anu and Antu's celestial chariot stood there ready, with gold to
the brim it was loaded. As the time for departing came, Anu to his children words of good-bye and
guidance said: Whatever Destiny for the Earth and the Earthlings intended, let it so be!
If Man, not Anunnaki, to inherit the Earth is destined,
let us which is destiny help. Give Mankind knowledge, up to only a measure of secrets
of the heavens and Earth them teach. Laws of justice and righteousness teach them,
then depart and leave! So did Anu to his children fatherly instructions give. Once more they hugged,
embraced and kissed, and from the new chariots' place Anu and Antu for Nibiru left.
The first to break the sorrowed silence was Marduk also known as Amun Ra with anger were
his words. What is this new Place of Celestial Chariots? of the others an
explanation he demanded. What after my exile without my knowledge has transpired?
When Enki of the decisions about the four regions to Marduk told,
Marduk's fury knew no bounds.......... Why will Inanna, a cause of Dumuzi's death,
her own region get? The decisions have been made, they cannot be altered! So did Enlil to Marduk
say. In separate sky ships to the Edin and its adjoining lands they returned. Sensing trouble,
Enlil told Ishkur to stay behind over the gold he shall watch. To commemorate Anu's visit,
a new count of time passage was introduced: By Earth years, not by Nibiru's Shars.
What on Earth transpired was to be counted. In the Age of the Bull, to Enlil dedicated,
was the count of Earth years begun. When to the Edin the leaders returned, the place of
the first civilized region. How to make bricks from mud the Anunnaki taught the earthlings,
therewith great cities to build. But where once cities of the Anunnaki alone had stood,
cities for both them and Earthlings now arose. Therein and in new cities for the great Anunnaki
sacred precincts were consecrated. Therein the Anunnaki with lofty abodes were provided,
Temples by Mankind they were called. Therein the Anunnaki leaders and houses as Lofty Lords were
served and worshiped. By number-ranks were they honored, the heirship to Mankind made known: Anu,
the heavenly, the rank of sixty held, to Enlil the fifty rank was given, On
Ninurta his foremost son did Enlil the same rank bestow. Next. in succession was the lord Enki,
the rank of the number forty he held; To Nannar, the son of Enlil and Ninlil, the rank of thirty
was assigned. To his son and successor, Utu, the rank of twenty was allotted.
Ten as a number-rank to the other Anunnaki leaders' sons was granted. Ranks by the
fives between the female Anunnaki and spouses were shared. When Eridu and Nibru-ki and their
temple-abodes were completed. In Lagash, the Girsu precinct for Ninurta was built,
his Black Sky bird there was kept. Eninnu, House of Fifty, was the temple-abode for Ninurta and
Bau his spouse called. The Supreme Hunter and the Supreme Smiter, weapons a gift of Anu,
the Eninnu protected. Where Sippar before the Deluge had been, on top of the mud-soil
Utu a new Sippar established. In the Ebabbar, the Shining House, an abode for Utu and his
spouse Aya was raised. From there Utu for Mankind laws of justice promulgated.
Where because of silt-mud the olden plans could not be followed, new sites were chosen. Adab,
a site from Shurubak not distant, for Ninharsag as a new center was made. The House of Succor and
Healing Knowledge was her temple-abode therein named. The genetic codes of how the Earthlings
were fashioned Ninharsag in its holy shrine kept. For Nannar, a city with straight streets, canals,
and wharves was provided; Urim was its name, House of the Throne's Seed was its temple-abode called,
the Moon's beams to the lands it reflected. Ishkur to the mountain
lands of the north returned, the House of Seven Storms his abode was called.
Inanna in Unug-ki resided, in the abode by Anu bequeathed to her she dwelt. Marduk also known
as amun ra and Nabu in Eridu dwelt. In the Edin their own abodes they did not have.
Now this is the account of the first City of Men and of kingship on Earth, And how Marduk
to build a tower schemed and wherefor Inanna the genetic code of earthlings was stole.
In the First Region, in the lands of Edin and in the cities with precincts,
By their Anunnaki lords the Earthlings handiworks and crafts were taught. Before
long were the fields irrigated, on canal and river boats soon they sailed. The sheepfolds
and granaries were overflowing, prosperity the land filled. Ki-Engi, Land of the Lofty Watchers,
the First Region it was called. Then to let the black-headed people a city of their own possess it
was decided; Kishi, Scepter City, it was called, in Kishi did the kingship of Man begin. Therein,
in consecrated soil, Anu and Enlil the Heavenly Bright Object implanted. In it Ninurta the first
king appointed, Mighty Man was his royal title. To make it a center for Civilized Mankind,
Ninurta to Eridu journeyed, The Genetic tablets that for kingship divine formulas
hold from Enki to obtain. Properly attired, with respect Ninurta Eridu entered, for the genetic
DNA codes of kingship he asked Enki, the lord who all the safeguards, fifty to Ninurta granted.
In Kishi were the black headed people with numbers to calculate were taught,
Heavenly Ningishzidda also known as Thoth, writing them he taught, heavenly Ningishzidda
beermaking them showed. In Kishi, by Ninurta guided, kilnwork and smithing proliferated,
Wheeled wagons, to male asses harnessed, craftily in Kishi first were fashioned. Laws
of justice and righteous behavior in Kishi were promulgated. It was in Kishi that the
people hymns of praise to Ninurta composed. Of his heroic deeds and victories they sang,
of his awe-inspiring Black Bird they chanted. How in faraway lands the bisons he subdued,
how the white metal to mix with copper he found. Ninurta's glorious time it was, with
the Constellation of the Archer he was honored. All the while Inanna in Unug-ki her lordship
in the Third Region awaited, All the while the domain of her own of the leaders she demanded.
The Third Region after the second one will come! her leaders thus assured her. Having seen how
Ninurta to Eridu journeyed, how the genetic codes of kingship he obtained, Inanna in her heart a
plan devised, to obtain from Enki she schemed. Her chambermaid Ninshubur to Eridu she dispatched,
a visit by Inanna to announce. On this hearing Enki to Isimud, his housemaster,
quickly instructions gave: The maiden, all alone, to my city Eridu her step is directing,
When all alone she will arrive, my inner chambers let her enter. Pour for her cold
water to freshen her heart, barley cakes with butter give her, Sweet wine prepare,
the beer vessels to the rim fill up! When Inanna alone the abode of Enki entered, Isimud Enki's
commands he followed; Then when Enki Inanna greeted, by Inanna's beauty he was overwhelmed.
With jewelry was Inanna bedecked, by her thin dress her body she revealed; When she bent down,
her vulva by Enki was thoroughly admired. From the wine cups sweet wine they drank, for beer
drinking a competition they had. Show me the dna genetic codes of the earthlings, Inanna to Enki
playfully said; let the codes in my hand hold! Seven, times in the course of the competition
Enki to Inanna DNA code to hold he gave. The divine formulas for lordship and kingship,
for priesthood and scribeship For lovedressing and for warring DNA formulas to Inanna Enki to hold
he gave. For music and singing, woodworking and metals and precious stones, Ninety-four genetic
codes for civilized kingdoms are needed Enki to Inanna gave. Holding her prizes tightly,
Inanna from the slumbering drunk Enki slipped away. To her Boat of Heaven she rushed out,
to soar away her pilot she instructed. When Enki from his slumber by Isimud was awakened. Get hold
of Inanna! to Isimud he said. When from Isimud that Inanna had already in her Boat of Heaven
departed Enki heard. To chase Inanna in Enki's sky ship Isimud he instructed. All the genetic
codes you must retrieve! To him he said. At the approach to Unug-ki Isimud Ianna's
Boat of Heaven intercepted, To return to Eridu and the wrath of Enki to face he made her.
But when Inanna back to Eridu was brought, the genetic codes were no longer with her.
To her chambermaid, Ninshubur, she gave them, to the House of Anu in
Unug-ki Ninshubur took them. In the name of my power, in the name of my father Anu,
I command you the genetic codes to return! So did Enki angrily to Inanna say, in his
abode captive he held her. When of this Enlil heard, to Eridu to face his brother he came.
By right I obtained them, Enki himself in my hand placed them! So did Inanna to Enlil her
grandfather say; the truth of that Enki meekly admitted. When the time term of Kishi shall be
completed, to Unug-ki kingship shall pass! So did Enlil declare. When Marduk all this did hear,
greatly he was enraged, his anger no bounds knew. Enough has my humiliation been! to his
father Enki, Marduk shouted. A sacred city of his own in the Edin from Enlil he forthwith
demanded. When Enlil to Marduk's appeal no heed paid, Marduk fate in his own hands grasped.
To a place that for Anu's arrival, before Unug-ki was selected, was considered, Nabu the Igigi and
their offspring from their dispersal lands were summoned. For Marduk therein a sacred city,
